title: Subinterval
text: The first step is to divide the interval from $$0$$ to $$2$$ into $$n$$ equal subintervals. These subintervals can be seen as rectangles.

title: Subinterval
text: How many subinterval or rectangle can we create in this problem?

subHints.title: Subinterval
subHints.text: Since $$n=4$$ is given in this problem, we can divide the interval from $$x=0$$ to $$x=2$$ into $$4$$ rectangles.\n##figure1.gif##

title: Find the step size
text: The step size or width of the rectangles can be found using $$Δx=\frac{b-a}{n}$$ where $$b$$ is the upper bound, a is the lower bound and $$n$$ is the number of rectangles.

title: Find the step size
text: What is the upper bound of the interval?

title: Find the step size
text: What is the lower bound of the interval?

title: Find the step size
text: For the $$4$$ rectangles, each rectangle has a width of $$Δx=\frac{2-0}{4}=0.5$$

title: Find the start and end points of each rectangle
text: Since we are asked to use the right-hand point approximation, we begin with the first rectangle whose right-hand point of $$x=0.5$$ and a width of $$0.5$$. Based on the illustration, we can see that the right-hand point of the next rectangles with the same width will be $$1, 1.5, 2$$ respectively.

title: Find the start and end points of each rectangle
text: Express in interval notation, what are the starting and ending points of the third rectangle?

title: Find the start and end points of each rectangle
text: Continuing the process, we obtain $$4$$ intervals which are $$[0, 0.5], [0.5, 1], [1, 1.5]$$ and $$[1.5, 2]$$.

title: Right-endpoint approximation
text: The right rectangle approximation is when you make the right hand points of the pieces the height of the rectangles. In other words, the height of each rectangle is equal to the value of the function at the right endpoint of its base.

title: Right-endpoint approximation
text: Using the right-endpoint approximation, what is the height of a rectangle in the interval $$[0.5, 1]$$ ?

title: Right-endpoint approximation
text: Using a right-endpoint approximation, the heights are $$f(0.5)=0.25, f(1)=1, f(1.5)=2.25, f(2)=4$$

title: Find the area of the rectangles
text: With the width and height just found, we can easily find the area of each rectangle using area of a rectangle formula $$A=w h$$ then add all of them up to get an approximation for the area under the curve.

title: Approximating the Area
text: Starting with $$x=0.5$$ from the right-hand point of the first rectangles, we have $$A=f{\left(x_1\right)} \Delta x+f{\left(x_2\right)} \Delta x+f{\left(x_3\right)} \Delta x+f{\left(x_4\right)} \Delta x=\Delta x \left(f{\left(x_1\right)}+f{\left(x_2\right)}+f{\left(x_3\right)}+f{\left(x_4\right)}\right)$$
